# Harmonic Scale in G# (Mode: Locrian #6)

The Harmonic scale in G# is also known as the Locrian #6 scale. This scale is derived from the G# Harmonic Minor scale starting from the 7th degree. It is called Locrian #6 because it has the characteristic diminished 5th of the Locrian mode, but with the added raised 6th degree.

## Notes and Intervals

The notes in the G# Harmonic scale (Locrian #6) are as follows:
- G#
- A
- B
- C#
- D
- E
- F#
- G#

The intervals in this scale are:  
Root (G#) - Minor 2nd (A) - Minor 3rd (B) - Diminished 4th (C#) - Diminished 5th (D) - Augmented 6th (E) - Major 7th (F#)

## Genre and Musical Flavor

The Harmonic scale in G# (Locrian #6) has a dark and mysterious sound due to the diminished 5th interval. The added raised 6th (E) gives it an exotic or mystical quality. This scale is commonly used in jazz and fusion music to create tension and add a sense of unease to the music.

## Songs that Use the Harmonic Scale in G# (Locrian #6)

1. **"Moments Notice" by John Coltrane**: This jazz standard features sections that use the Harmonic scale in G# to create tension and add a dynamic element to the improvisation.
   
2. **"Night Passage" by Weather Report**: A fusion jazz piece that incorporates the Locrian #6 scale in G# to build suspense and introduce a unique harmonic flavor to the composition.
 
3. **"Flamenco Sketches" by Miles Davis**: In this modal jazz piece, the Harmonic scale in G# (Locrian #6) is used to set the moody atmosphere and explore different tonal colors within the improvisation sections.
